Tanya_Tucker:
{{short description|American singer and songwriter}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Tanya Tucker | image = TanyaTuckerGraceland02202020.jpeg | caption = Tucker performing at [[Graceland]] in 2020. | birth_name = Tanya Denise Tucker | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|10|10}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1571873/tanya-tucker-celebrates-birthday-in-downtown-nashville/|title=Tanya Tucker Celebrates Birthday in Downtown Nashville|website=Cmt.com|access-date=3 May 2018|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102132318/http://www.cmt.com/news/1571873/tanya-tucker-celebrates-birthday-in-downtown-nashville/|archive-date=2 January 2018}} | birth_place = [[Seminole, Texas]], U.S. | instrument = {{hlist|Vocals}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[outlaw country]]|[[country rock]]}} | background = solo_singer | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter}} | years_active = 1971–present | label = {{hlist|[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]|[[MCA Records|MCA]]|[[Arista Records|Arista]]|[[Capitol Records Nashville|Capitol Nashville]]|[[Liberty Records|Liberty]]|[[Capitol Records|Capitol]]|Tuckertime|Saguaro Road|[[Fantasy Records|Fantasy]]}} | website = {{URL|tanyatucker.com}} }} '''Tanya Denise Tucker''' (born October 10, 1958){{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=420/1}} is an American country music singer and songwriter who had her first hit, "[[Delta Dawn]]", in 1972 at the age of 13. During her career Tucker became one of the few child performers to mature into adulthood without losing her audience; she had a streak of top-10 and top-40 hits.[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p133079/biography|pure_url=yes}} Tanya Tucker biography] at Allmusic She has had several successful albums, several [[Country Music Association]] award nominations, and hit songs including 1973's "[[What's Your Mama's Name (song)|What's Your Mama's Name?]]" and "[[Blood Red and Goin' Down]]", 1975's "[[Lizzie and the Rainman]]", 1988's "[[Strong Enough to Bend (song)|Strong Enough to Bend]]", and 1992's "[[Two Sparrows in a Hurricane]]". Tucker's 2019 album ''[[While I'm Livin']]'' won the [[Grammy Award]] for [[Best Country Album]], and "[[Bring My Flowers Now]]" from that same album won Tucker a shared songwriting Grammy for [[Best Country Song]].[https://www.vulture.com/2020/01/grammy-winners-2020-the-full-list.html Grammy Winners List 2020] by Zoe Haylock, Vulture.com, January 27, 2020. Tucker’s latest album is a 2023 critically acclaimed collaboration with [[Brandi Carlile]] called ''[[Sweet Western Sound]]''. Tucker was inducted into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] on October 22, 2023.{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/country-music-hall-of-fame-members-tanya-tucker-patty-loveless-1234708278/|title=Tanya Tucker, Patty Loveless Lead Country Music Hall of Fame's 2023 Inductees|first1=Stephen L.|last1=Betts|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=April 3, 2023}} ==Early life== She was born in [[Seminole, Texas]], the youngest of three children born to Alma Juanita (née Cunningham; 1927–2012) and Jesse Melvin "Beau" Tucker (1927–2006). Prior to managing Tanya's career, Beau was a heavy equipment operator, so the family moved often as he sought better work. Her early childhood was spent primarily in [[Willcox, Arizona]], where the only radio station in town, [[KHIL]], played country music. The Tuckers attended concerts of country stars such as [[Ernest Tubb]] and [[Mel Tillis]], and Tanya's sister [[LaCosta Tucker|LaCosta]] was praised in the family for her vocal abilities. At the age of eight, Tanya told her father that she also wanted to be a country singer when she grew up. When the Tuckers moved to [[St. George, Utah]], Juanita took Tanya to audition for the film ''[[Jeremiah Johnson (film)|Jeremiah Johnson]]''. Tanya did not win the bigger role for which she tried out, but she was hired, as was her horse, as a bit player. About this time, she also received one of her first musical breaks, when her father drove the family to [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] for the [[Arizona State Fair]], on the chance that the featured performer, country singer [[Judy Lynn]], could use Tanya in her show. Tanya sang for the fair's entertainment managers, and she was engaged to sing at the fair itself. Tucker made her debut with Mel Tillis, who was so impressed by her talent that he invited her onstage to perform. In 1969, the family moved to [[Henderson, Nevada]], where Tucker regularly performed. Eventually, she recorded a demonstration tape that gained the attention of songwriter [[Dolores Fuller]], who sent it to producer [[Billy Sherrill]], the head of [[artists and repertoire]] at [[Sony Music|CBS Records]]. Sherrill was impressed with the demo tape and signed the teenage vocalist to [[Columbia Records]]. ==Career== ===1972–1979: Teen country star=== [[File:Tanya Tucker.png|thumb|upright|Tucker in a 1973 promotional portrait for Columbia Records.]] Sherrill initially planned to have Tucker record "[[The Happiest Girl in the Whole USA]]", but she chose "[[Delta Dawn]]"{{snd}}a song Billy Sherrill heard [[Bette Midler]] sing on ''[[The Tonight Show]]''{{snd}}instead as her first single while [[Donna Fargo]], the writer of "The Happiest Girl in the Whole USA", released her own version as a single. Released in May 1972, the song became a hit, peaking at number six on the country chart and scraping the bottom of the pop chart. At first, Columbia Records tried to downplay Tucker's age, but soon word leaked out and she became a sensation.Bob Schieffer. "Legends: Tanya Tucker" (interview), ''CBS Sunday Morning'', 2 August 2020. A year later, Australian singer [[Helen Reddy]] scored a number-one U.S. pop hit with her version of "Delta Dawn". "I thank the lucky stars and the Good Lord for that song," Tucker told ''[[Nine-O-One Network Magazine]]'' in 1988. "If I cut it now for the first time I think it would be a hit. I was fortunate to have latched onto that one, and that was all Sherrill's doing. If it hadn't been for Sherrill, I probably would have been a rodeo queen or something."Dickerson, James L. (April 1988). "Good Friends Make the Best Records". ''Nine-O-One Network Magazine'', pp. 32–35. Her second single, "Love's the Answer", also became a top-10 hit later in 1972. Tucker's third single, "What's Your Mama's Name", became her first number-one hit in the spring of 1973. Two other number ones{{snd}}"Blood Red and Goin' Down" and "[[Would You Lay with Me (In a Field of Stone) (song)|Would You Lay with Me (In a Field of Stone)]]" followed, establishing Tucker as a major star. In 1975, she signed with [[MCA Records]], where she had a string of hit singles that ran into the late 1970s. Among these hits was "Lizzie and the Rainman", which became a number-one country hit, and also became Tucker's only top-40 pop music hit, peaking at number 37. It also peaked among the top 10 on the [[adult contemporary]] charts at the time. Tucker has a string of top-10 country hits under MCA between 1975 and 1978, including "[[San Antonio Stroll]]", "[[Here's Some Love]]", and "[[It's a Cowboy Lovin' Night]]". In 1977, she recorded "You Taught Me How to Cry," a duet with [[Hoyt Axton]] on his album ''Snowblind Friend.'' In 1978, she decided to radically change her image and cross over to rock with her ''[[TNT (Tanya Tucker album)|TNT]]'' album. Despite the controversy over the record and its sexy cover, it went gold the following year. The two hit singles from the album were "I'm a Singer, You're the Song", and "[[Texas (When I Die)]]". The latter reached number five on the country charts, and its B-side, "[[Not Fade Away (song)|Not Fade Away]]", a [[Buddy Holly]] cover, peaked at number 70 on the [[Billboard Hot 100]]. ===1979–1984: Sales decline and personal battles=== By the end of the 1970s, her sales were declining{{snd}}in 1980 she only had two hits, one of them was "Can I See You Tonight?". Also in 1980, she recorded a few singles with [[Glen Campbell]], with whom she was romantically linked. In addition to recording, she also made her feature-film debut in ''[[Hard Country (1981 film)|Hard Country]]'', although she did have small roles in ''[[Jeremiah Johnson (film)|Jeremiah Johnson]]'' (1972) and the television miniseries ''[[The Rebels (miniseries)|The Rebels]]'' (1979). She also had begun drinking in her late teens, and she explained how it started:
"You send your ass out on the road doing two gigs a night and after all that adoration go back to empty hotel rooms. Loneliness got me into it."
In 1978, Tucker moved to Los Angeles to try, unsuccessfully, to broaden her appeal to pop audiences, and was quickly captivated by the city's nightlife. She also said that she "was the wildest thing out there. I could stay up longer, drink more and kick the biggest ass in town. I was on the ragged edge."{{Cite web |last=Nelson |first=Dick |date=2013-06-26 |title=Country Classic Flashback to Feature Tanya Tucker |url=https://minnesotasnewcountry.com/country-classic-flashback-to-feature-tanya-tucker/ |access-date=2022-10-30 |website=98.1 - Minnesota's New Country |language=en}} Despite having a top 10 hit in March 1983 ("Feel Right") {{Cite web|url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Archive-Billboard-IDX/IDX/80s/1983/BB-1983-03-12-OCR-Page-0049.pdf|title=Billboard Not Country Singles|website=Americanradiohistory.com}} from her first and only Arista album ''[[Changes (Tanya Tucker album)|Changes]]'', she struggled to have her music played on the radio. By mid-1983, her singles were no longer making the top 40. She moved to Nashville after her breakup with Campbell in 1982 and began to lead a more secluded life. Finally, in 1988, her family confronted her and persuaded her to enter the [[Betty Ford Center]]. ===1986–1997: Comeback=== In 1986, Tucker signed with [[Capitol Records]]; she returned to the charts with "[[One Love at a Time]]", which climbed to number three. Her career was revitalized with 1986's ''[[Girls Like Me]]'', an album that spawned four top-10 country singles. In 1988, she had three number-one country singles: "[[I Won't Take Less Than Your Love]]" (with [[Paul Davis (singer)|Paul Davis]] and [[Paul Overstreet]]), "[[If It Don't Come Easy]]", and "[[Strong Enough to Bend (song)|Strong Enough to Bend]]".{{cite web |title=Tanya Tucker |website=Cmt.com|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/tanya-tucker |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180709181021/http://www.cmt.com/artists/tanya-tucker |archive-date=2018-07-09 }} Her music was now more [[country pop]]-styled and up-tempo, but this material made Tucker popular again. Between 1988 and 1989, Tucker enjoyed one of her most popular years on the charts, racking up eight country top-10 hits in a row. Her albums around this time were also achieving "Gold" certifications by the [[RIAA]], after selling 500,000 copies. A ''Greatest Hits'' album followed in 1989. It also contained a new single called "[[My Arms Stay Open All Night]]". Radio responded well; the song peaked at number two. In 1988, Tucker was nominated by the [[Country Music Association]] for "Female Vocalist of the Year", and was nominated for other major awards during this time. Her contribution to the country music genre was rewarded when the Country Music Association voted her the "Female Vocalist of the Year" in 1991, though she missed the event, having just given birth to her second child. Eight consecutive singles reached the top 10 in the early 1990s, including "[[Down to My Last Teardrop]]", "[[(Without You) What Do I Do with Me]]", and "[[Two Sparrows in a Hurricane]]". In 1990, Tucker was named "Female Video Artist of the Year" by [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]]. Although by the 1990s, she no longer had number-one hits, many singles came close peaking in the country top five, as well as the top 10. Tucker was one of the most successful female country artists at the time. She became one of the few teen stars to find success in her adult years. Her 1993 album ''[[Greatest Hits 1990-1992]]'' rose to number 15, and also went to number 18 on the Top Country Albums chart. Liberty Records was changed to Capitol Nashville in 1994. By the 1990s, Tucker was a 20-year veteran in country music, though she was only in her mid-30s. In 1994, "[[Hangin' In (song)|Hangin' In]]" was her last top-five hit, as well as her last top-10 hit for a while. That year, she performed at the [[half-time]] show at [[Super Bowl XXVIII]]. In 1996, she was one of the top-10 most-played artists of the year, and at the time was also [[Capitol Records]]' biggest signed female artist. In 1997, she returned to the top 10 on the country charts for the last time with the hit, "[[Little Things (Tanya Tucker song)|Little Things]]", which peaked at number nine. That year she was inducted into the [[Texas Country Music Hall of Fame]]. ===2000–present: Music career today=== {{BLP sources section|date=January 2013}} [[File:TanyaRyman01122020.jpg|thumb|right|Tucker performing at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] in 2020.]] In 2002, Tucker founded Tuckertime Records, allowing her to retain control of the recording process and release the singles she wished to release. The same year, she issued ''[[Tanya (album)|Tanya]]'', her first album in five years, which was distributed through Capitol Records. In 2002, Tucker was ranked number 20 on CMT's 40 Greatest Women of Country Music. In 2005, she released an album, ''Live at Billy Bob's Texas''. In 2005, she also contributed two songs to a tribute album to [[Bob Wills]], called ''A Tribute to Bob Wills 100th Anniversary''. In 2005, she released a book, ''100 Ways to Beat the Blues on Fireside'', which included tips on shaking the blues, from some of Tucker's friends such as [[Willie Nelson]], [[Brenda Lee]], [[Little Richard]], and [[Burt Reynolds]]. Tucker recorded an album, ''Lonesome Town'', around 2007, but it has never been released. The same year, she recorded a live concert at the [[Renaissance Center]] in December. Tucker also sang a duet with country music artist [[Billy Joe Shaver]], of Shaver's song, "Played the Game Too Long", on his album, ''Everybody's Brother'', released in September 2007. In 2009, Tucker signed a one-time deal with Saguaro Road Records{{cite web|url=http://www.saguaroroad.com/|title=Saguaro Road website|website=Saguaroroad.com|access-date=3 May 2018|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170704212714/http://www.saguaroroad.com/|archive-date=4 July 2017}} from [[Time-Life]]. Tucker's "Lonesome Town" project was put on hold to do the first cover album of her career, ''[[My Turn (Tanya Tucker album)|My Turn]]'', which was released in June 2009 and placed number 27 on the ''Billboard'' country charts. The first single, "[[Love's Gonna Live Here]]", was released to radio and was also available as a digital single. It is a remake of the classic hit by [[Buck Owens]]. The album includes classic country hits such as "[[Wine Me Up]]", "[[Lovesick Blues]]", "[[You Don't Know Me (Eddy Arnold song)|You Don't Know Me]]", "Ramblin' Fever", "Walk Through This World With Me", "Big Big Love", "[[Crazy Arms]]", "After The Fire Is Gone", and "[[Oh Lonesome Me]]". Tucker appeared on [[Terri Clark]]'s 2012 album ''[[Classic (Terri Clark album)|Classic]]'' in a remake duet of her first single "Delta Dawn". In June 2017, Tucker was featured in ''Rolling Stone'' as one of the 100 Greatest Country Artists of All Time.{{cite magazine |author=Jon Freeman |date=June 15, 2017 |title=100 Greatest Country Artists of All Time: 67. Tanya Tucker |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/100-greatest-country-artists-of-all-time-w486191/tanya-tucker-w486280 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905054935/http://www.rollingstone.com/country/lists/100-greatest-country-artists-of-all-time-w486191/tanya-tucker-w486280 |archive-date=September 5, 2017 }} After the death of former flame Glen Campbell on August 8, 2017, Tucker released her first single since 2009, "Forever Loving You", a song co-penned by Tennessee State Senator [[Rusty Crowe]].{{cite news |author=Zach Vance |date=August 11, 2017 |title=Tennessee lawmaker co-wrote Glen Campbell tribute song |newspaper=Johnson City Press |url=http://www.johnsoncitypress.com/Music/2017/08/11/Tennessee-lawmaker-co-wrote.html?ci=stream&lp=3&p=1 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818161922/http://www.johnsoncitypress.com/Music/2017/08/11/Tennessee-lawmaker-co-wrote.html?ci=stream&lp=3&p=1 |archive-date=August 18, 2017 }} The song's release the following day, on the eve of Campbell's funeral, drew ire and criticism being exploitative.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/music/glen-campbells-former-fling-wrote-a-love-song-about-himand-its-pretty-gross-8340652|title=Glen Campbell's Former Fling Wrote a Love Song About Him{{snd}}And It's Pretty Gross|last=Slaughter|first=Duke|date=2017-08-15|website=Ocweekly.com|access-date=2018-01-05|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171020025532/http://www.ocweekly.com/music/glen-campbells-former-fling-wrote-a-love-song-about-himand-its-pretty-gross-8340652|archive-date=2017-10-20}} Tucker claimed that a portion of the proceeds will benefit the [[Alzheimer's Foundation of America]],{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/tanya-tucker-on-glen-campbell-ill-forever-love-you-glen-w496988|title=Tanya Tucker on Glen Campbell: 'I'll Forever Love You, Glen'|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=2018-01-05|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171014140121/http://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/tanya-tucker-on-glen-campbell-ill-forever-love-you-glen-w496988|archive-date=2017-10-14}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-entertainment-news-updates-august-tanya-tucker-glen-campbell-1502379071-htmlstory.html|title=A 'devastated' Tanya Tucker releases song to honor former flame Glen Campbell|last=D'Zurilla|first=Christie|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=2018-01-05|language=en-US|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105070157/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-entertainment-news-updates-august-tanya-tucker-glen-campbell-1502379071-htmlstory.html|archive-date=2018-01-05}} but the foundation stated it was not involved in the promotion and has not received any funds.{{cite news |author=Rachel Desantis |date=August 27, 2017 |title=Glen Campbell's widow Kim reportedly thinks Tanya Tucker is exploiting his death: It's 'callous and disrespectful' |newspaper=New York Daily News |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/glen-campbell-widow-thinks-tanya-tucker-exploiting-death-article-1.3446759 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829121759/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/glen-campbell-widow-thinks-tanya-tucker-exploiting-death-article-1.3446759 |archive-date=August 29, 2017 }} Tucker released ''[[While I'm Livin']]'', her first collection of original material since 2002's ''Tanya'', in 2019 via [[Fantasy Records]]. It was produced by [[Shooter Jennings]] and [[Brandi Carlile]], with Carlile brought onto the project after initially being approached for songs by Jennings but after having professed such an admiration of Tucker and her work, Jennings felt it necessary for her to co-produce the record alongside him.{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/tanya-tucker-brandi-carlile-shooter-jennings/|title=Tanya Tucker Teams With Brandi Carlile, Shooter Jennings for New Documentary + Album|first=Carena|last=Liptak|website=Theboot.com|date=8 February 2019 }} Tucker performed "[[Bring My Flowers Now]]" at [[Loretta Lynn]]'s all-star 87th birthday concert at Nashville's [[Bridgestone Arena]] with Carlile playing piano.{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/tanya-tucker-while-im-living-loretta-lynn-concert/|title=WATCH: Tanya Tucker Performs New Song at Loretta Lynn's Birthday Bash|first=Carena|last=Liptak|website=Theboot.com|date=2 April 2019 }} The album's first single, "Hard Luck", was released on June 28, along with its accompanying music video.{{cite web |last1=Liptak |first1=Carena |title=WATCH: Tanya Tucker's 'Hard Luck' Turns Into a Winning Streak in New Video |url=https://theboot.com/tanya-tucker-hard-luck-music-video/ |website=Theboot.com |access-date=June 29, 2019 |language=en |date=2016}} On January 26, 2020, Tanya Tucker won her first two Grammy Awards for "[[Bring My Flowers Now]]" and "[[While I'm Livin']]". Tucker released a live album, [[Live from the Troubadour]] on October 16, 2020. In a 2021 interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', Tucker revealed that she was working on a follow-up to ''While I'm Livin''' with Carlile and Jennings.{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/tanya-tucker-new-album-brandi-carlile-1125165/|title = Tanya Tucker Says She's Working on a New Album with Brandi Carlile|magazine = [[Rolling Stone]]|date = 9 February 2021}} Tucker collaborated with [[RuPaul]] for "This is Our Country" in September 2021.{{cite magazine | last=Freeman | first=Jon | title=Tanya Tucker, RuPaul's 'This Is Our Country' Collab Is Fit for a Queen | magazine=Rolling Stone | date=2021-09-10 | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/tanya-tucker-rupaul-this-is-our-country-duet-1223654/ | access-date=2024-06-21}} During her 2022 set at [[Stagecoach Festival]], Tucker revealed completing a new album. Tanya announced her studio album ''[[Sweet Western Sound]]'' on April 5, 2023, releasing the first single, "Kindness". ''Sweet Western Sound'' was produced by Tucker along with [[Brandi Carlile]] and [[Shooter Jennings]], and released June 2, 2023, on [[Fantasy Records]].{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/tanya-tucker-announces-brandi-carlile-produced-album-sweet-western-sound-1234709963/|title = Tanya Tucker Recruits Brandi Carlile for New Album ''Sweet Western Sound''|magazine = [[Rolling Stone]]|date = 5 April 2023}}{{Cite magazine|url=https://americansongwriter.com/tanya-tucker-shares-new-single-kindness-from-forthcoming-new-album/|title = Tanya Tucker Shares New Single "Kindness" from Forthcoming Album|magazine = [[American Songwriter]]|date = 5 April 2023}} ===Outlaw image=== Tucker is one of the few and best-known female country singers to be classified as an "Outlaw" in the [[Outlaw country]] movement,{{by whom|date=December 2021}} which was most popular in the late 1970s. As Tucker matured by the end of the 1970s, her Outlaw image grew.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} Like the other Outlaw artists in the business at the time ([[Johnny Cash]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Kris Kristofferson]], [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Jessi Colter]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[David Allan Coe]], [[Hank Williams Jr.]]), Tucker was able to combine qualities of country and rock music into her voice to make the Outlaw sound that was popular at the time. These qualities could be heard on some of her biggest hits at the time, including 1978's "Texas (When I Die)". Tucker also had a spirit of independence, which was another Outlaw quality.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} She ranked number nine on CMT Greatest Outlaws: The Dirty Dozen, the only woman to appear on that list.{{Cite episode |title=CMT Greatest Outlaws: The Dirty Dozen |episode-link= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m0FNzggvdQY |access-date=2022-07-15 |series=CMT Outlaws |series-link= |first= |last= |network=Country Music Television |station= |date=2004 |season= |series-no= |number=16}} As the 1980s progressed, Tucker continued to add the Outlaw qualities to her hits.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} At the beginning of the 1990s, Tucker was still identified{{by whom|date=December 2021}} as an Outlaw.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} Today, Tucker continues to be recognized as one,{{by whom|date=December 2021}} regularly attending Outlaw events among regular shows.{{citation needed|date=December 2021}} [[Gretchen Wilson]] made reference to Tucker in her 2004 hit song "[[Redneck Woman]]",{{cite journal |last1=Hubbs |first1=Nadine |title="Redneck Woman" and the Gendered Poetics of Class Rebellion |journal=Southern Cultures |date=2011 |volume=17 |issue=4 |page=54 |doi=10.1353/scu.2011.0061 |jstor=26217352 |s2cid=143443783 |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/26217352 |access-date=15 July 2022}} and Tucker appears briefly in the video of the song, showing Tucker with other Outlaws.{{cite web |last1=Wilson |first1=Gretchen |title=Redneck Woman |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=82dDnv9zeLs |via=[[YouTube]]|access-date=15 July 2022}} ==''The Return of Tanya Tucker''== Decades after Tucker slipped from the spotlight, musician [[Brandi Carlile]] collaborated with her on an [[While I'm Livin'|album]], as well as a documentary based on Tucker's life. ''[[The Return of Tanya Tucker: Featuring Brandi Carlile]]'' was released in New York and Los Angeles on October 21, 2022, and nationwide on November 4. It was accompanied by the track "Ready As I'll Never Be".{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/tanya-tucker-ready-as-ill-never-be/ | title=LISTEN: Tanya Tucker Shares Powerful 'Ready as I'll Never Be' Ahead of Revealing Documentary |website=Tasteofcountry.com| date=21 October 2022 }} ==Other works== Tucker appeared as a celebrity judge on ''[[Dance Fever]]'' in 1979. She published a 1997 autobiography, ''Nickel Dreams: My Life''.{{cite book |last1=Tucker |first1=Tanya |last2=Cox |first2=Patsi Bale |title=Nickel dreams: my life |date=1997 |publisher=Hyperion |location=New York |oclc=38922645 |url=http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/38922645 |access-date=15 July 2022}} She starred in her own [[reality show]], ''[[Tuckerville]]'', on [[TLC (TV network)|TLC]] in 2005. It ran for two seasons for 18 episodes.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0470978/episodes#season-2 Tuckerville] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909014932/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0470978/episodes |date=2015-09-09 }} on IMDB The show covers an in-depth visit with Tucker in her home with her family. Tucker continues to perform for the military doing benefits with newer country acts such as Eric Agnew and [[Cole Deggs & the Lonesome]]. In 2019, she launched her own brand of tequila called Cosa Salvaje.{{Cite web |title=Tanya Tucker Launches Cosa Salvaje Tequila |url=https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/tanya-tucker-launches-cosa-salvaje-tequila-1028042419 |access-date=2022-07-06 |website=Markets.businessinsider.com |language=en}}{{Cite web |date=2021-10-28 |title=Tanya Tucker's Cosa Salvaje Tequila Announces Partnership With Tennessee Breast Cancer Coalition |url=https://www.nashvillenoise.com/tanya-tucker-cosa-salvaje-tequila-breast-cancer/ |access-date=2022-07-06 |website=Nashville Noise |language=en-US}} ==Personal life== Tucker had a relationship with [[Glen Campbell]] in the early 1980s.{{cite magazine|last1=Doyle|first1=Patrick|title=Glen Campbell, 'Rhinestone Cowboy' Singer Who Fused Country and Pop, Dead at 81|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/glen-campbell-dead-at-81|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=August 8, 2017|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170808211952/http://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/glen-campbell-dead-at-81|archive-date=August 8, 2017}} She also dated [[Merle Haggard]], [[Andy Gibb]], and [[Don Johnson]]. She later had a relationship with actor [[Ben Reed]], with whom she had daughter Presley Tanita (born July 5, 1989) and son Beau "Grayson" (born October 2, 1991).{{cite web|title=Tanya Tucker Full Bio|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0876019/bio|website=IMDb.com|access-date=8 August 2017|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109030943/http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0876019/bio|archive-date=9 January 2017}} Tucker has had an [[on-again, off-again relationship]] with Jerry Laseter, a Nashville musician. They were engaged in 1997 and again in 1999. Just days before their 1999 wedding, Tucker canceled the ceremony when she discovered she was pregnant with her third child, Tucker's daughter Layla LaCosta (born June 25, 1999),{{cite web|title=Interview With Tanya Tucker |url=http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0403/23/lkl.00.html |website=Edition.cnn.com|date=March 23, 2004 |access-date=8 August 2017 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170311004536/http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0403/23/lkl.00.html |archive-date=11 March 2017 }} saying she did not want to walk down the aisle pregnant in her wedding dress. Laseter was co-producer of Tucker's albums in 2002 (''Tanya''), 2005 (''Live at Billy Bob's Texas''), and 2009 (''My Turn''). Tucker's brother is Don (deceased) and her sister is country singer [[La Costa]]. In 2022, Tucker sold her Brentwood, Tennessee, home (purchased three years earlier for $1,510,000){{Cite web |date=April 29, 2019 |title=Davidson County Trustee's Office |url=https://www.davidsonportal.com/gis/file.php?file=201904290038789|website=Davidsonportal.com}} for $2,275,000.{{Cite web |title=Stacy's Music Row Report- Music Row Report |url=http://stacyharris.com/musicrowreport.html |access-date=2022-04-15 |website=Stacyharris.com}} ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! scope="col" | Award ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Recipient(s) and nominee(s) ! scope="col" | Category ! scope="col" style="width:7%;"| Result ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |{{Abbr|Ref.|References}} |- ! style="text-align:center;" scope="row" rowspan = "17" |[[Academy of Country Music Awards]] | style="text-align:center;"|1972 | rowspan = "4" | Tanya Tucker | Most Promising Female Vocalist | {{won}} | style="text-align:center;" rowspan = "17"|{{cite web |title=Winners |url=https://www.acmcountry.com/winners |website=Academy of Country Music |access-date=February 24, 2020 |language=en}} |- | style="text-align:center;"|1975 | Top Female Vocalist of the Year | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;"|1987 | rowspan = "2" | Top Female Vocalist | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan = "3" |1988 | {{nom}} |- | rowspan = "2" | "[[Strong Enough to Bend (song)|Strong Enough to Bend]]" | Song of the Year | {{nom}} |- | Single Record of the Year | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;"|1989 | Tanya Tucker | Top Female Vocalist | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan = "2" |1990 | "[[Don't Go Out]]" {{small|(with [[T.
